Authors: Pavel B Klimov, Sergey V Mironov, Barry M OConnor
Title:
Convergent and unidirectional evolution of extremely long
aedeagi in the largest feather mite genus, Proctophyllodes (Acari:
Proctophyllodidae): evidence from comparative molecular and
morphological phylogenetics
Abstract:
Phenotypic evolution of proctophyllodid feather mites
(400+ species) appears to be greatly influenced by traits related to
reproductive success (>87.5% of a total of 32 traits) and male
genitalic traits (21.9%). Because sexual selection could the major
evolutionary driver in this system, we test the theoretical expectation
that genitalic or sexually dimorphic traits should evolve both rapidly
and divergently as compared to other traits. We inferred a
time-calibrated molecular phylogeny (6 genes, 8571 nt aligned, no
missing data) for 133 taxa of proctophyllodid mites and 40 outgroups.
Comparisons of the average number of character state changes inferred on
10,696 Bayesian stationary trees indicate that male genitalic or
sexually dimorphic traits do not evolve significantly faster than other
traits (p = 0.537 and p=0.819, respectively). However, among the male
genitalic traits, a trait related to the length of the aedeagus
experienced extremely fast rates of evolution and was detected as a
statistical outlier. In this character, the transitions between short,
long, and several intermediate states occurred in both directions. In
contrast, the evolution of extremely long aedeagi (nearly as long as the
body) occurred unidirectionally and irreversibly. This surprising result
may be due to constraints imposed by the female spermathecal canal,
which is also very long and may impede pumping sperm by short aedeagi.
Extremely long aedeagi evolved several times independently, giving rise
to several monophyletic lineages. Several of these lineages were lumped
together by taxonomists to form easy-to-distinguish but apparently
artificial species-groups. Male genitalic traits, thus, can introduce
false synapomorphies that could affect morphology-based phylogenetic
inference. For the most species-rich genus, Proctophyllodes, we develop
a predictive classification of species-groups completely reconciling
molecular and morphological data.
